title: Elijah and Ahaziah
shortSummary: This chapter recounts the rebellion of Moab against Israel following King Ahab's death and the illness of King Ahaziah after an accident. Ahaziah seeks counsel from a pagan god, Baalzebub, prompting Elijah to deliver God's judgment that Ahaziah will die for his lack of faith. The chapter highlights God's sovereignty and the authority of His prophet Elijah.
timeline: c. 850 BC - Reign of Ahaziah in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Ahaziah
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who falls ill and seeks guidance from Baalzebub, provoking God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Elijah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of the LORD who confronts Ahaziah's messengers and pronounces God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Captain of Fifty (third)
keyCharacters.description: The third military leader sent by Ahaziah who humbly pleads for mercy and is spared by Elijah.

definitions.definition: A Philistine deity worshiped in Ekron, often associated with false gods and demonic powers.
A divine messenger sent by God to communicate His will, often representing God's presence and authority.
A belt or sash worn around the waist, often symbolizing readiness for service or ministry.
A military officer commanding fifty soldiers, representing the king’s authority in enforcing his commands.

outline.heading: Moab’s Rebellion and Ahaziah’s Injury
outline.description: Moab rebels against Israel after Ahab’s death, and Ahaziah suffers a severe injury, setting the stage for his misguided inquiry to a pagan god.

outline.heading: Elijah’s Prophetic Judgment
outline.description: God sends Elijah to confront Ahaziah’s messengers, declaring that Ahaziah will die because he sought help from Baalzebub instead of the true God.

outline.heading: The Messengers’ Report and Identification of Elijah
outline.description: The messengers return with Elijah’s message and describe him, confirming his identity as the man of God.

outline.heading: Elijah and the Captains of Fifty
outline.description: Ahaziah sends three captains with their soldiers to summon Elijah; God’s judgment consumes the first two captains with fire, but the third pleads for mercy and is spared.

outline.heading: Elijah Confronts Ahaziah and Pronounces Death
outline.description: Elijah goes with the third captain to Ahaziah, reiterates God’s judgment, and Ahaziah dies as prophesied, with Jehoram succeeding him.

outline.heading: Record of Ahaziah’s Reign
outline.description: The chapter concludes by referencing the official chronicles for further details about Ahaziah’s acts.

application: Trust in the LORD alone for guidance and healing rather than turning to worldly or false sources.
Recognize the authority of God’s prophets and His word, responding with obedience rather than defiance.
Approach God with humility and reverence, as demonstrated by the third captain who sought mercy.
Understand that sin and rebellion against God have serious consequences, but God’s mercy is available to those who repent.

keyVerses.text: But the angel of the LORD said to Elijah the Tishbite, Arise, go up to meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and say unto them, Is it not because there is not a God in Israel, that ye go to enquire of Baalzebub the god of Ekron?
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s displeasure with Ahaziah’s idolatry and establishes Elijah’s role as God’s prophet confronting false worship.

keyVerses.text: And Elijah answered and said to the captain of fifty, If I be a man of God, then let fire come down from heaven, and consume thee and thy fifty. And there came down fire from heaven, and consumed him and his fifty.
keyVerses.significance: This dramatic display of divine power confirms Elijah’s authority and God’s judgment against rebellion.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto him, Thus saith the LORD, Forasmuch as thou hast sent messengers to enquire of Baalzebub the god of Ekron, is it not because there is no God in Israel to enquire of his word? therefore thou shalt not come down off that bed on which thou art gone up, but shalt surely die.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the seriousness of seeking help from false gods and affirms the certainty of God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: So he died according to the word of the LORD which Elijah had spoken. And Jehoram reigned in his stead in the second year of Jehoram the son of Jehoshaphat king of Judah; because he had no son.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms the fulfillment of God’s prophetic word and the continuation of the Davidic line in Judah.
